instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PLT_RST_L: What is PLT_RST_L? This is an abbreviation of “PLT_RESET_L” – when you see “PLT_RST_L", assume the person meant to type PLT_RESET_L.
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.CPUIMVP_VR_ON: What is CPUIMVP_VR_ON? CPUIMVP_VR_ON is a signal that tells the buck converter responsible for PPVCORE_S0_CPU to turn on and create CPU vcore voltage. This comes from ALL_SYS_PWRGD – once ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present, CPUIMVP_VR_ON will be present. .

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Voltages present minus <SIGNAL>PPVTT_S0_DDR_LDO</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Scattered liquid-damage. Everything is present on this board except <SIGNAL>PPVTT_S0_DDR_LDO</SIGNAL>. <SIGNAL>DDRVTT_EN</SIGNAL> (<SIGNAL>MEMVTT_EN</SIGNAL>) is not present. I've repaired main power circuit, replaced BIOS just in case. Everything about this board seems in order other than that one voltage (and the voltages that would come after it - CPU etc.) I haven't seen this one before. Any ideas would be greatly appreciated. I've attached pictures. They get shrunk pretty bad by the forum uploader but it might help a little.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Voltages present minus <SIGNAL>PPVTT_S0_DDR_LDO</SIGNAL>
threads.message: What is voltage on <SIGNAL>PLT_RST_L</SIGNAL>? If it is high then <SIGNAL>MEMVTT_EN</SIGNAL> should be pulled high through <RESISTOR>R2810</RESISTOR>.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Voltages present minus <SIGNAL>PPVTT_S0_DDR_LDO</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
0V on <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL>\
I'm trying to dig and see where this comes from and why I might not be getting this voltage. Nothing so far.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Voltages present minus <SIGNAL>PPVTT_S0_DDR_LDO</SIGNAL>
[SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Voltages present minus <SIGNAL>PPVTT_S0_DDR_LDO</SIGNAL>
threads.message: No, it looked like CPU Vcore required <SIGNAL>PPVTT_S0_DDR_LDO</SIGNAL> to be present. I thought I would need <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> in order to get <SIGNAL>CPUIMVP_VR_ON</SIGNAL> to enable <CHIP>U7400</CHIP>. Is that not true, is this just a CPU Vcore issue? I have 0.50V on <SIGNAL>CPUIMVP_VR_ON</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Voltages present minus <SIGNAL>PPVTT_S0_DDR_LDO</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Well, you need to figure out why there is no ALL SYS PWRGD. <CHIP>U7300</CHIP> is excluded from that, so some other voltage must be missing.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Voltages present minus <SIGNAL>PPVTT_S0_DDR_LDO</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Thanks, got it. I missed the fact that <SIGNAL>PVCCSA_EN</SIGNAL> was not present. Replaced <CHIP>U7600</CHIP> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7100</TRANSISTOR> and it's up and running. Thanks for your help.
